Authors: Chen X.; Hu Z.; Jing Y.; Wang C.
Author full names: Chen, Xiaojiao (58731963000); Hu, Zhebing (58910604300); Jing, Yuhui (58125991500); Wang, Chengliang (57726574000)
Title: The Development and Alleviation of Humanistic Artificial Intelligence in the Digital Age Education: A Content Analysis research
Source title: ICAAI 2024 - Conference Proceedings of the 2024 8th International Conference on Advances in Artificial Intelligence
Affiliations: Zhejiang University of Technology, College of Education, Zhejiang, Hangzhou, China; Zhejiang University of Technology, College of Foreign Languages, Zhejiang, Hangzhou, China; East China Normal University, Faculty of Education Shanghai, Shanghai, China
Authors with affiliations: Chen X., Zhejiang University of Technology, College of Education, Zhejiang, Hangzhou, China; Hu Z., Zhejiang University of Technology, College of Foreign Languages, Zhejiang, Hangzhou, China; Jing Y., Zhejiang University of Technology, College of Education, Zhejiang, Hangzhou, China; Wang C., East China Normal University, Faculty of Education Shanghai, Shanghai, China
Abstract: Human-Centered Artificial Intelligence (HCAI) is flourishing in the education sector in the digital intelligence era. This study employs content analysis, selecting 21 papers related to HCAI applications in education from six databases as the research subjects. The study finds that both domestic and international research share common focal points but differ in implementation strategies and application areas. Through content analysis, the study discusses in detail the research themes, intrinsic values, and risk limitations of HCAI in the education field, aiming to provide reference and guidance for future educational policy and technology development. © 2024 Copyright held by the owner/author(s).
Index Keywords: Ambient intelligence; Application in education; Content analysis; Digital age; Domestic research; Education sectors; Focal points; Human-centered; International researches; Research subjects; Smart education

Title: Application of Large Language Models for Digital Libraries
Source title: Proceedings of the ACM/IEEE Joint Conference on Digital Libraries
Affiliations: Informatics, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Champaign, IL, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hu X., Informatics, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Champaign, IL, United States
Abstract: Digital library collections are valuable documents, which contain vast amounts of knowledge. The rise of artificial intelligence (AI) technologies, especially Large Language Models (LLM), has made an impact on various domains, and may also shift the focus of digital library services from storing and preserving information to utilizing and extracting knowledge from that information. We expect to add value created by LLMs to existing digital library methods so that users can better leverage the information stored in digital library collections. This research aims to improve access to digital library collections by providing users with classification labels and summaries to help easily find their works of interest leveraging large language models. Two expected major benefits are: (1) Enhancing metadata in the form of classification labels, which will help users discover and use digital library collections more easily. (2) Providing summaries of works stored in the digital library to aid researchers in finding works of interest without having to read the entire content, which will help remediate the information overload problem.  © 2024 Copyright held by the owner/author(s).
Author Keywords: Artificial intelligence; Digital libraries; Machine learning; Natural language processing
Index Keywords: Digital libraries; Artificial intelligence technologies; Classification labels; Digital library collections; Language model; Language processing; Library methods; Library services; Machine-learning; Natural language processing; Natural languages; Classification (of information)

Authors: Krutova I.A.; Stefanova G.P.; Krutova O.V.; Dergunova O.Y.
Author full names: Krutova, Irina A. (57302828500); Stefanova, Galina P. (59682207600); Krutova, Olga V. (59681956900); Dergunova, Olesya Yu. (57970395500)
Title: The application of artificial intelligence and the internet of things to solve challenges of practical relevance
Affiliations: Astrakhan State University Named after V.N. Tatishchev, Astrakhan, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Krutova I.A., Astrakhan State University Named after V.N. Tatishchev, Astrakhan, Russian Federation; Stefanova G.P., Astrakhan State University Named after V.N. Tatishchev, Astrakhan, Russian Federation; Krutova O.V., Astrakhan State University Named after V.N. Tatishchev, Astrakhan, Russian Federation; Dergunova O.Y., Astrakhan State University Named after V.N. Tatishchev, Astrakhan, Russian Federation
Abstract: The need to implement the National Strategy for Digitalization and the Development of Artificial Intelligence brings to the fore the issue of training specialists with innovative thinking, who are capable of solving practical challenges using artificial intelligence technology and the Internet of Things. To develop new skills in the area of developing and implementing artificial intelligence technologies, there is a need to review strategies and methods of teaching at all levels of education. The article analyses the best practices in the application of digital technology across sectors of the AI economy, including transportation, industry, healthcare, and others. It also discusses the content of the "Artificial Intelligence Systems"discipline, which aims to develop methods for solving professional and social issues using AI. The article proposes ways to teach students how to explore and apply "smart"approaches to solving professional and everyday problems. The methodology for organizing students' activities when completing a project task to create a smart greenhouse is described. Students work in teams to design technical devices that automatically maintain the normal value of certain parameters (humidity, temperature, lighting, etc.); test them using simulators and software tools; install working models; and make technological forecasts about the possibilities of using artificial intelligence to optimize processes. © 2025 Author(s).

Title: Simplifying scholarly abstracts for accessible digital libraries using language models
Source title: Proceedings of the ACM/IEEE Joint Conference on Digital Libraries
Affiliations: Indiana University Bloomington, Bloomington, IN, United States; Montana State University, Bozeman, MT, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wang H., Indiana University Bloomington, Bloomington, IN, United States; Clark J., Montana State University, Bozeman, MT, United States
Abstract: Standing at the forefront of knowledge dissemination, digital libraries curate vast collections of scientific literature. However, these scholarly writings are often laden with jargon and tailored for domain experts rather than the general public. As librarians, we strive to offer services to a diverse audience, including those with lower reading levels. To extend our services beyond mere access, we propose fine-Tuning a language model to rewrite scholarly abstracts into more comprehensible versions, thereby making scholarly literature more accessible when requested. We began by introducing a corpus specifically designed for training models to simplify scholarly abstracts. This corpus consists of over three thousand pairs of abstracts and significance statements from diverse disciplines. We then fine-Tuned four language models using this corpus. The outputs from the models were subsequently examined both quantitatively for accessibility and semantic coherence, and qualitatively for language quality, faithfulness, and completeness. Our findings show that the resulting models can improve readability by over three grade levels compared to the original abstracts, while maintaining fidelity to the original content. Although commercial state-of-Theart models still hold an edge, our models are much more compact, can be deployed locally in an affordable manner, and alleviate the privacy concerns associated with using commercial models. We envision this work as a step toward more accessible libraries, improving our services for young readers and those without advanced degrees.  © 2024 Copyright held by the owner/author(s).
Author Keywords: Accessible language; Artificial intelligence; Deep learning; Language model; Text simplification
Index Keywords: Contrastive Learning; Deep learning; Accessible language; Deep learning; Domain experts; Fine tuning; General publics; Knowledge dissemination; Language model; Reading level; Scientific literature; Text simplification; Semantics

Authors: Li L.; Wang C.; Chen J.; Sun H.; Zhang H.
Title: Artificial Intelligence Education Policy Analysis From International Perspective
Source title: ICETM 2024 - Proceedings of the 2024 7th International Conference on Educational Technology Management
Affiliations: School of Educational Technology, Beijing Normal University, Beijing, China
Authors with affiliations: Li L., School of Educational Technology, Beijing Normal University, Beijing, China; Wang C., School of Educational Technology, Beijing Normal University, Beijing, China; Chen J., School of Educational Technology, Beijing Normal University, Beijing, China; Sun H., School of Educational Technology, Beijing Normal University, Beijing, China; Zhang H., School of Educational Technology, Beijing Normal University, Beijing, China
Abstract: With the development of the application of artificial intelligence technology in the field of education, countries and international organizations have introduced relevant policies to address the opportunities and challenges it brings to education. A thorough analysis of these policies on a global scale is important for guiding educational innovation and ensuring the effectiveness of technology applications. This article uses a content analysis method, taking 26 artificial intelligence education policies from major countries and international organizations as samples, and employs a”policy tool—policy content” two-dimensional analysis framework to quantitatively analyze the policy texts to reveal the characteristics of international artificial intelligence education policies. The study finds that the current types of policy tools are mainly supply-oriented and environmental-oriented, focusing more on dimensions such as quality assessment and assurance, resource environment construction, and future talent cultivation in terms of content elements. Supply-side tools provide resource support for the construction of intelligent educational environments and innovative cultivation services for the improvement of teachers’ and students’ intelligent literacy; environmental tools build institutional standards for the quality assurance of intelligent education and create organizational strategies to achieve inclusive and fair education. Finally, the study proposes suggestions for the formulation and optimization of artificial intelligence education policies from four aspects: strengthening talent cultivation, focusing on independent research and development, deepening international exchanges, and systematic policy design, to promote the high-quality development of teaching and education in the digital age. © 2024 Copyright held by the owner/author(s).
Author Keywords: Artificial Intelligence Education; Content Analysis Method; Generative Artificial Intelligence; Policy Texts; Policy Tools

Authors: Liu S.; Wu C.; Zhou Y.; Wang H.; Sun H.
Author full names: Liu, Shuguang (55724747000); Wu, Chengwei (58854759000); Zhou, Yunyan (59291452700); Wang, Hongsheng (58677155800); Sun, Hao (59720752700)
Title: From ChatGPT to SORA-AIGC Empowering the Digital Transformation in Higher Education
Source title: ICETM 2024 - Proceedings of the 2024 7th International Conference on Educational Technology Management
Affiliations: School of Mechanical and Electrical Eng., Huaibei Institute of Technology, Anhui, China; School of Mechanical and Electrical Eng., Huangshan University, Anhui, China
Authors with affiliations: Liu S., School of Mechanical and Electrical Eng., Huaibei Institute of Technology, Anhui, China; Wu C., School of Mechanical and Electrical Eng., Huangshan University, Anhui, China; Zhou Y., School of Mechanical and Electrical Eng., Huangshan University, Anhui, China; Wang H., School of Mechanical and Electrical Eng., Huangshan University, Anhui, China; Sun H., School of Mechanical and Electrical Eng., Huangshan University, Anhui, China
Abstract: The emergence of ChatGPT and Sora is two sensational events in the history of artificial intelligence development, jointly demonstrating the powerful functions of generative and universal artificial intelligence based on large models. As a technology system that integrates multiple functions such as text, image, and video processing, AIGC (Artificial Intelligence Generated Content) not only brings technological breakthroughs to the education field due to its emergence of multiple platforms, terminals, and modalities, but also brings challenges and opportunities to the current teaching and research system. The endogenous value of AIGC is reflected in its nonlinearity, multiscale, self-organization, adaptability, difficulty in regulation, signal transmission, feedback loop, and historical dependence, which is of great benefit to the digital transformation of higher education today. Empowering teaching, AIGC has promoted the shift of teaching mode from the binary structure of”teacher - student” to the ternary structure of”teacher - machine - student”, promoted the shift of teaching content from manual production to intelligent production, and catalyzed the evaluation mode of”knowledge+literacy”; Empowering learning, AIGC has promoted the ubiquity of learning space, met the personalized needs of full coverage of the learning process, and formed a human-machine collaborative learning mode; Empowering education, AIGC has promoted the shift of educational philosophy towards high-level ability cultivation and comprehensive literacy cultivation, and innovated the education model of interdisciplinary integration. © 2024 Copyright held by the owner/author(s).
Author Keywords: AIGC; ChatGPT; Digital transformation; Higher education; Sora
Index Keywords: Adversarial machine learning; Contrastive Learning; Federated learning; Teaching; Artificial intelligence generated content; ChatGPT; Digital transformation; High educations; Large models; Multiple function; Powerful functions; Sora; Teachers'; Technology system; Students

Authors: Guo P.; Zhang Q.; Tian C.; Xue W.; Feng X.
Title: Digital Human Techniques for Education Reform
Source title: ICETM 2024 - Proceedings of the 2024 7th International Conference on Educational Technology Management
Affiliations: School of Software, Northwestern Polytechnical University, Shaanxi, Xi’an, China; School of Economics and Management, Harbin Institute of Technology at Weihai, Shandong, Weihai, China; Shenzhen Research Institute of Northwestern Polytechnical University, Northwestern Polytechnical University, Guangdong, Shenzhen, China; School of Computer Science and Engineering, Tianjin University of Technology, Tianjin, China; Research Center for Social Computing and Information Retrieval, Harbin Institute of Technology, Heilongjiang, Harbin, China; Guangdong Key Laboratory of Intelligent Information Processing, Shenzhen Key Laboratory of Media Security, Shenzhen University, Guangdong, Shenzhen, China
Authors with affiliations: Guo P., School of Software, Northwestern Polytechnical University, Shaanxi, Xi’an, China; Zhang Q., School of Economics and Management, Harbin Institute of Technology at Weihai, Shandong, Weihai, China; Tian C., School of Software, Northwestern Polytechnical University, Shaanxi, Xi’an, China, Shenzhen Research Institute of Northwestern Polytechnical University, Northwestern Polytechnical University, Guangdong, Shenzhen, China; Xue W., School of Computer Science and Engineering, Tianjin University of Technology, Tianjin, China; Feng X., Research Center for Social Computing and Information Retrieval, Harbin Institute of Technology, Heilongjiang, Harbin, China, Guangdong Key Laboratory of Intelligent Information Processing, Shenzhen Key Laboratory of Media Security, Shenzhen University, Guangdong, Shenzhen, China
Abstract: The rapid evolution of artificial intelligence, big data, and generative AI models has ushered in significant transformations across various sectors, including education. Digital Human Technique, an innovative technology grounded in advanced computer science and artificial intelligence, is reshaping educational paradigms by enabling virtual humans to simulate human behavior, express emotions, and interact with users. This paper explores the application of Digital Human Technique in education reform, focusing on creating immersive, intelligent classroom experiences that foster meaningful interactions between teachers and students. We define Digital Human Technique and delve into its key technical components such as character modeling and rendering, natural language processing, computer vision, and augmented reality technologies. Our methodology involves analyzing the role of educational digital humans created through these technologies, assessing their impact on educational processes, and examining various application scenarios in educational reform. Results indicate that Digital Human Technique significantly enhances the learning experience by enabling personalized teaching, increasing engagement, and fostering emotional connections. Educational digital humans serve as virtual teachers, interactive learning aids, and facilitators of emotional interaction, effectively addressing the challenges of traditional educational methods. They also promote a deeper understanding of complex concepts through simulated environments and interactive digital content. © 2024 Copyright held by the owner/author(s).

Authors: Qiu X.; Deng H.; Li P.; He W.
Title: Mathematical Intelligence Blended Teaching Model Based on Knowledge Graph – A Case Study of Surgical Nursing
Source title: Frontiers in Artificial Intelligence and Applications
Affiliations: School of Nursing, Xiangnan University, Hunan, Chenzhou, China
Authors with affiliations: Qiu X., School of Nursing, Xiangnan University, Hunan, Chenzhou, China; Deng H., School of Nursing, Xiangnan University, Hunan, Chenzhou, China; Li P., School of Nursing, Xiangnan University, Hunan, Chenzhou, China; He W., School of Nursing, Xiangnan University, Hunan, Chenzhou, China
Abstract: Digital intelligence refers to the integration of digital technologies and intelligent digitalization, which encompasses the development and application of data as a new productive force for societal benefit. Blended teaching has become essential in adapting to the educational advancements of the digital intelligence era. The deep integration of digital intelligence technology and classroom teaching has become the new norm of education and teaching reform. As the core technology of artificial intelligence (AI), a knowledge graph can express the knowledge system visually, integrate educational resources, collect learning process data to realize the monitoring and diagnosis of the learning process and meet the diversified needs of intelligent education applications. It is an effective tool for deeply integrating nursing education and AI. As healthcare technology continues to evolve and knowledge is rapidly updated, students need to continually learn and update their knowledge base so as to keep up with professional development. Therefore, this study explored the practical strategy of digital–intelligent blended teaching of Surgical Nursing by reshaping and integrating the course content, sorting out the course knowledge system, and constructing the course knowledge graph to enable students to systematically master the learning content and access high-quality learning resources. It provided a reference for the digital transformation of higher education, with a view to promoting the consolidation of students’ mastery of basic knowledge, improving students’ clinical thinking and comprehensive ability to implement holistic care for patients, and cultivating students’ ability to acquire and use cutting-edge knowledge. © 2025 The Authors.

Authors: Yi J.; Sheng Y.; Xiong D.; Zhang Z.
Title: Exploration of the “Cognitive” Curriculum Teaching System for Digital Signal Processing Course under the Background of New Engineering Disciplines
Source title: ICETM 2024 - Proceedings of the 2024 7th International Conference on Educational Technology Management
Affiliations: School of Information Science and Engineering, Wuhan University of Science and Technology, Hubei, Wuhan, China
Authors with affiliations: Yi J., School of Information Science and Engineering, Wuhan University of Science and Technology, Hubei, Wuhan, China; Sheng Y., School of Information Science and Engineering, Wuhan University of Science and Technology, Hubei, Wuhan, China; Xiong D., School of Information Science and Engineering, Wuhan University of Science and Technology, Hubei, Wuhan, China; Zhang Z., School of Information Science and Engineering, Wuhan University of Science and Technology, Hubei, Wuhan, China
Abstract: In the new era of rapid information advancement, traditional curriculum teaching systems no longer meet the demands of cultivating talents for information and artificial intelligence. In response to the construction needs of the Ministry of Education’s”New Engineering Disciplines”, a new “cognitive” curriculum teaching system is designed for the”Digital Signal Processing” course as an example. The proposed”cognitive” curriculum teaching system includes three levels: the universal courses based on conceptual methods, the intermediary courses supported by technological applications, and advanced courses led by academic frontiers. The system integrates multiple modern teaching modes, further optimizes the course evaluation system guided by Outcome-Based Education (OBE) principles, and updates the course teaching content in real time. This integrates the principles of signal processing into the field of artificial intelligence, fostering exceptional engineering talents who can apply innovative solutions to meet the demands of national economic development. © 2024 Copyright held by the owner/author(s).

Authors: Fulantelli G.; Taibi D.; Splendore S.; Fisichella M.
Author full names: Fulantelli, Giovanni (6507394668); Taibi, Davide (36651883900); Splendore, Sergio (55877908600); Fisichella, Marco (36607884300)
Title: 1st Workshop on Detecting Trust, Authority, Sense and Knowledge in Online News Media Production
Source title: WSDM 2025 - Proceedings of the 18th ACM International Conference on Web Search and Data Mining
Affiliations: Institute for Educational Technology, National Research Council of Italy, Palermo, Italy; Dept. of Social and Political Sciences, Università degli Studi di Milano, Milano, Italy; L3S Research Center of Leibniz Univ. Hannover, Hannover, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Fulantelli G., Institute for Educational Technology, National Research Council of Italy, Palermo, Italy; Taibi D., Institute for Educational Technology, National Research Council of Italy, Palermo, Italy; Splendore S., Dept. of Social and Political Sciences, Università degli Studi di Milano, Milano, Italy; Fisichella M., L3S Research Center of Leibniz Univ. Hannover, Hannover, Germany
Abstract: This workshop explores the intersection of media trust, journalistic authority and the role of Artificial Intelligence (AI) within platform-based media ecosystems. As social media becomes a primary source of news for global audiences media uses are changing public discourses and trust in journalism. The workshop includes papers that use innovative methods to analyze media trust and intertwining role of platforms (e.g. Facebook, Instagram, TikTok, and X). Key topics include AI-powered news curation, personalized news feeds and the impact of algorithm-driven content. Advanced techniques such as natural language processing, sentiment analysis and semantically enriched entity models are central to understanding and visualizing interactions between users, news providers and content. By integrating these approaches, the workshop aims to foster interdisciplinary discussions, propose new analytical frameworks and contribute to the development of balanced, transparent and fair news ecosystems in the digital age. © 2025 Copyright held by the owner/author(s).
Author Keywords: Artificial Intelligence; Authority; Journalisms; Social Media; Trust; Web content Analysis
